awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Systematic Investigation of the Spanish Subjunctive
awd_abstract_narration:
The Romance language family is known to have a productive contrast between two verbal 'moods', the subjunctive and the indicative. Subjunctive-selecting clauses are those in which a speaker expresses a desire, demand, doubt, emotion, possibility, purpose, or cause. According to traditional grammar, Spanish, being a Romance language, also adheres to these restrictions. However, contrary to what is expected, Spanish-speakers select the indicative in many 'subjunctive-requiring' environments. Many frameworks used to describe the choice of mood focus exclusively on prescriptively correct patterns of selection. As a result, the unexpected use of indicative in subjunctive clauses is left untouched by traditional semantic theory. This dissertation research project, thus, aims to develop a semanto-pragmatic account of mood that can explain mood variation that is non-prescriptive. However, prior to developing such an account, the current project seeks to confirm the extent to which this variability exists, as well as the dialects in which it is present. In this way, a more comprehensive description of the Spanish mood system that accounts for both dialect-specific and non-prescriptive variability will become available. This will lead to a better understanding of Spanish, the second most common language spoken in the U.S.

A corpus study will be carried out in order to obtain naturally-occurring examples of mood use in the eight traditionally subjunctive-requiring contexts. The items obtained will be adapted for inclusion in an Acceptability Judgment Task (AJT). The objective is to test how specific contexts affect participant views on the acceptability of either mood. Results from the AJTs and follow-up interviews will provide greater insight into the semanto-pragmatic factors conditioning mood variation in environments in which it is not supposed to occur. The participants forming part of the experiment will come from various Spanish dialects. Since no systematic, widespread study of Spanish has been carried out, data from this project will expand on the body of knowledge that currently exists. Additionally, in terms of a theoretical standpoint, such an investigation will help to fill the research gaps related to non-prescriptive uses of mood.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
According to numerous Spanish grammars, the subjunctive is required in the complements of desiderative predicates (querer que ‘to want that’), directive predicates (aconsejar que ‘to advise that’), purpose clauses (para que ‘in order that’), causative predicates (hacer que ‘to make that’), emotive-factive predicates (alegrarse de que ‘to be happy that’), negated epistemic verbs (no creer que ‘to not believe that’), dubitative predicates (dudar que ‘to doubt that’), as well as modal verbs and expressions (ser posible que ‘to be possible that’). However, it is not uncommon for some of these predicates to accept indicative subordinate clauses. The objective of the present study was, thus, to identify the supposedly subjunctive environments in which mood variation is exhibited, along with any semantic consequences that are associated with its occurrence.

Previous findings from Faulkner (2021a) demonstrate that the mood variation occurring in emotive-factive clauses relates to the (un)informativeness of the subordinate proposition; i.e., if the proposition in question is addressee-new or addressee-old. In line with these findings, the current investigation sought to investigate if the relationship between speaker intent and prior addressee knowledge would affect choice of mood in the eight aforementioned, traditionally subjunctive environments. To accomplish this objective, two hundred and twenty-three native Spanish-speakers completed a 128-item Acceptability Judgment Task (AJT) focused on rating separate instances of subjunctive and indicative, based on the (un)informativeness of the complement in question.

Statistical analyses of participant responses revealed that, although the subjunctive is preferred mood in the environments in which it is traditionally expected, with certain subjunctive-normative predicates, indicative clauses are acceptable. Whereas non-realistic, preference-based clauses (e.g., desiderative, directive, causative, and purpose clauses) are inflexibly subjunctive, the complement clauses of emotive-factives and verbs of uncertainty (negated epistemics, dubitatives, modals) accept the indicative if the speaker intends to add the affirmative or negated proposition to the common ground. It was observed that the likelihood that the indicative is used in these cases increases when the proposition (affirmative or negated) is informative. These findings suggest that the Spanish mood system involves a split between two types of subjunctives: one that is required in non-realistic, preference-based contexts, and another that is default in subordinate clauses containing propositions that are at least somewhat realistic. In the case of the latter, subjunctive may be substituted with indicative, especially when the particular complement is informative.

In addition to the above-mentioned initial study, a follow-up investigation was carried out  to examine the possible acceptability of the indicative in directive clauses. Although described as inflexibly subjunctive, the initial study showed that in certain contexts the indicative was acceptable. Thus, in order to better understand this pattern, 102 (additional) native Spanish-speakers completed a 32-item AJT, focused solely on choice of mood after directive predicates. Results showed that the indicative becomes strongly preferable to subjunctive when the embedded complement contains a verb or expression that is of the same modality type and strength as the matrix directive; i.e., when there is modal concord. However, with respect to all other instances, that is, when there is no modal concord, subjunctive was observed to be the only acceptable option.

Intellectual Merit: Funding for this project has provided the means to: compensate hundreds of subjects for their participation; purchase various materials and resources; and make travel plans pertaining to the future related research. The findings made so far have been transformative in that they offer a theoretically informed description of dialect-non-specific, non-standard mood variation in Spanish. They further show that traditional understandings of mood as related to subjunctive-normative predicates are mostly applicable to non-realistic, preference-based predicates, since unlike the former, emotive-factives and verbs of uncertainty exhibit a certain degree of context-specific variability. Because no previous empirical studies have compared variation between moods across Spanish dialects, the present study adds to the body of knowledge that currently exists, providing a more comprehensive description of the Spanish mood system.

Apart from in the present dissertation, findings from this project are to be published in Bolearis - An International Journal of Hispanic Linguistics, in the June, 2022 issue (see: Faulkner, T. (2022). The Two Spanish Subjunctives: The Required and Default Subjunctives. Bolearis: An International Journal of Hispanic Linguistics, 11(1)). Additionally, at least two to three additional papers will come from the project’s findings, one which is already in preparation.

Broader Impacts: With a more comprehensive account of the Spanish mood system, instructors will be better equipped to tackle and account for divergences from textbook Spanish. In other words, the gap between prescriptive mood use and authentic mood use may be filled with access to these theoretical descriptions. Additionally, findings from the current project serve as a descriptive basis for further studies on the semantics of the subjunctive mood.
